Talking about influences and copying: This is something I think our culture screws up. Copying is an incredibly useful step of the learning process, and we shouldn't feel bad about our early copying of our influences. It's one of the best exercises developing the technical mastery that lets us be original later. Even later in our careers, copying can be a useful exercise, the same way a master musician doesn't stop playing the scales for practice.

As long as one gives credit to one's influences, there shouldn't be shame in practicing a respectful copy.

Here's a minor flex: Friends of mine and I have competitions where we shoot (among other targets) cards edge-on like this from 20-25 feet away with muzzleloading firearms. I've done it with a 1770s style flintlock rifle, a 1640s style wheellock rifle, and a 1620s style smoothbore matchlock. It is tricky, and the standard is to cut the card from the front. Sounds odd, but you can whiff the shot by a fraction of an inch and the wake of the bullet will suck the back edge of the card into it, cutting the card part way through from the back.

That flexed, good thoughts on evolving from imitation to innovation. That's the path of a classical atelier trained artist. I can't claim a major "Aha!" moment like yours in my career. More like a long series of lower case "aha." But kudos for recognizing that moment and following it.

Doc Edgerton used to walk around with postcards of his famous photos in his front pocket, including that the photo of that split playing card.  How do I know?  Because, many moons ago, I was riding in an elevator with my youngest brother who was visiting me at college, and Doc stepped onto the elevator.  I introduced my brother to him, and Doc reaches into his pocket and gives my brother a postcard of one of his photos.  After he stepped off the elevator, I looked at my brother and just said, "You have no idea how famous that guy is."  We ALL loved Doc.  He was the epitome of cool at school.  RIP, Doc.

I have come to understand this struggle. Being so inspired by certain artists, that you start to copy their style without even noticing it. I have caught myself in this practice and I have really started to try and think about what makes me different? My art is through music. So when I practice, I just try and slow down. Instead of playing what sounds good based on what I have heard before from artists who inspire me, I try to just completely clear my mind and play whatever it is that comes from my heart. Cliche I know, but it is true. If you can just completely let go, and forget about what’s “right” and what’s “wrong” and do whatever it is in that moment that you feel... You realize that is true artistry. Because that’s all art is. Art isn’t something “right” or “wrong”. It’s self expression to the highest degree and is essential to letting out all of your emotions.

As a professional artist I have had that experience of initially only being able to make art based on the authority of my education. My early work sought to paint in the image of "pretty" things I had seen before. As I matured, though, things that impressed me on a different basis, much of that a deep interest in how people tell, and scale, stories, began to take over. (Briefly, the scaling of a story is how it starts in something small- like Tom Sawyer's home life- and blossoms into voyages on the Mississippi. Another example is the flowers in some corner of an epic painting by Frederick Church.)

Now much of my work happens in series, as in, for a book to tell about my region, in East Texas.
Good work connecting us to your humanity.

I’ve found there is a trap to being “inspired”. You can find yourself trying to conform to the... I guess the style of the inspiration. It was pointed out to me several years ago that I’m a steampunk. I had no idea what steampunk was. I always just thought I was poor and creative. So I looked up STEAMPUNK! In all it’s glory. At first it was awesome that other people were doing the same stuff I have been doing. Then I found the trap. I had started to loose my style by trying to refine my steampunkyness. I was inspired to be less of what I’ve spent my life becoming. I’m poor and creative. I’m not an artist mimicking life. I’m not a creator of functioning art and strange toys. I’m a worker with a talent for making tools for what I need to do. Don’t trap yourself in inspiration for the sake of being inspired. Just do you and be happy with what you’re doing for yourself. I promise if you like what you’re doing others will like watching you do it.

I like sci-fi writing and world...well technically universe building. I base my stuff off alot of other things like video games and star trek n all that. Though recently I havent done much of it, after my main ext HD decided "F you, I quit!" and i couldnt access it anymore I lost pretty much all the things i wrote or well typed but ya.
A good number of the stories and such I come up with are similar in plot to trek / star wars n such mostly cause....well thats just what i find entertaining for one thing and for another, sure you can put out a more original piece but then those tend to be the more...artsy type of things. Some like it but most everyone can enjoy trek / star wars / star gate / halo. I wish i could draw so I could also try out making a ...i dont want to say manga but I dont know a more accurate term for what it would be, but its another thing ive had planned. What I try to do though is still while using some of the less realistic concepts of those shows ie warp n what not, I try to make things make more sense. I hate the idea of things just happening because plot. I like things to feel like a natural logical progression and keep in line with the lore of the universe its in. Also I dont care much for the trope of a group of rebels or underdogs always being the good guys. I prefer having the heros in the large powerful ships with massive numbers and then finding ways to make an interesting story out of it. I use to write all the time in highschool and alot when I was in the Army. Not so much now though, and Id say my stuff while it got better over time is still very amature. I tend to stop from time to time from creating anything, one thing i love using is space engineers, old game but i find it fun and I use it for ship designs. Making different things from civilian craft to massive warships as part of one of the sci-fi universes Im ...building? making up? whatever the correct term is.

When we're new to a field that has subjective elements, it's helpful to focus on duplicating other people's work precisely, because what they did is 100% objective (from our perspective), and so trying to duplicate it imposes a discipline upon us, a standard to objectively measure our capability. When we jump prematurely into what we want, and our niche, it's hard to know for sure if what we are producing is what it is because it's the best expression of ourselves or only because we lack the ability to be more precise or don't know how to do better. After we've disciplined ourselves to duplicate someone else's work or technique, we can make conscious choices to deviate from it as little or as much as we want -- even abandon it, as a conscious choice, instead of from inexorable incompetence masquerading as self-expression.

I started playing guitar a couple years ago and over time I stopped learning songs from other people and took what I learned from the songs I learned to develop certain styles in which I play. When I write music down, I play more of a subtle and peaceful style, as opposed to when I improvised playing where I play a quick blues/rock style. I personally believe that to this day, the people I looked at the most as a starting guitarist have helped shape the way I play. From my improvised style I believe it comes from Stevie Ray Vaughn, BB King, Muddy Waters, and different aspect of Jimi Hendrix. My written down music is more of Estas Tonne, Morf, Tash Sultana, and Kaki King. Though my written down style is a lot slower than the artists listed above, I developed the chord structure and subtle note placement from listening to their music constantly.

I'm an engineer like you, and I got started in photography in undergrad using some really primitive CCD cameras for astronomy. I put it down for a long time and got back into it a few years ago, and what's interesting is that all of my experience in engineering between then and now (I work on radar systems for the Navy) means that I understand the guts of today's modern digital cameras really well. SNR, signal processing, thermal noise, etc. This understanding has really influenced my photography, in particular my work with high dynamic range scenes like fire breathers and missile launches. Just so that you are aware that people may be confused about the shockwave near the end of the video. They will think its the shockwave of the bullet such as a sonic boom shock wave of a plane--it isnt. Its the shock wave of the explosion from the barrel of the gun before the bullet hits. If you look at the shockwave--it is not associated with the bullet and at supersonic--the bow wave shock wave of a bullet or object cannot be in front of the object. Also the angle and shape of the wave shadow does not match. Why is it not a perfect radius ahead of the bullet?--that I cannot figure out.

My parents were humanities professors at Caltech - a science and engineering school of some reputation. While there, my dad was the David R. Smith mentioned on this Wikipedia page about the founding of the Baxter Art Gallery - the records of which are now part of the Smithsonian: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baxter_Art_Gallery.

The students at Caltech then (as probably now) were great people, who had such fertile imaginations and active minds. But one thing they tended to lack before arriving at Caltech was an exposure to that part of life that makes us distinctly human - the humanities. My father went above and beyond his duties as a professor to try and bring something of that to the students he loved so much. In that, he was largely successful. When word got out that he was terminally ill, he received more than a thousand letters from all over the world, from students whose lives he had affected and who remembered him fondly. His nickname on campus? “Dirty Dave”, because he wasn’t above telling a ribald joke in class.

Whatever benefits science has to offer us, they are enhanced when scientists understand the human context in which their science will be put to use. Art, literature, and music are useful for making well-rounded scientists. To that, I would personally add faith, as I do not believe that faith in God is incompatible with good science. It is all of those things that make a complete human being.

I don't know what he actually meant by it, but when Steve Jobs said "Good artists borrow, great artists steal" to me it means that you start with someone else's idea (borrow), but then you take what's there and make it your own (steal).  You own it now.  It's not somebody else's idea anymore, it's your own thing.

Dr Dre has used samples from Barbara Streisand.  Shoe shave been designed after cars.  Outside influences are almost always a major factor in greatness, often directly but always at least indirectly.  Just look at biomimicry for the most blatant examples.  Steve Jobs once gave a speech about it to a grad class.  Pay attention to the whole world, not just your own bubble.  I once had a full out racist, misogynist bigot help heavily influence my ideas on objectivity and I'm eternally grateful to him for unintentionally revealing truths to me about the how "right" and "wrong" are just concepts as opposed to absolutes.

I think what I do, and what a lot of people do, is you start by copying others (as you said), but more because you're learning the process and figuring out how to do cool things.  Then (again, at least for me) as you discover how to do it, you naturally start thinking of ways to do similar but different variations -- derivative works.  You might also bring in elements you learn from other sources and combine techniques or ideas, and you tweak things to do what works best for yourself and your ideas.  Eventually, you get further and further from your original source of inspiration and into more original territory -- and that becomes your own style.
Creativity is knowing how to hide your sources.

Hey Destin, I was thinking about how the curl of the card moves towards the camera. Looking at pictures on Google Images, it seems to always curl toward the right side of the bullet. With the face of the card towards the camera: if shot from the left it curls towards the camera, and if shot from the right it curls away. Looking at a picture of the rifling it seems to be a clockwise rotation. I'm still curious as to why both top and bottom halves curve in the same direction. The top might be intuitive as being 'pushed' to the right of the bullet's axis but if that were the case, the bottom having the same forces should curl in the opposite direction. Maybe it's due to a factor such as where the tip of the bullet is or the difference between the shear strength in the two different layers of the card?

Game development is my creative hobby. I'd been working on skills for a long time, but never really started until I played Undertale. I've always loved stories for the way they impact people personally, in different ways for each person who experiences it. I've also always loved playing games that have fast paced button pushing, especially involving crazy acrobatics or something. Undertale brought the two together for me and really showed me how storytelling can be made even more personal by incorporating the actions of the reader/player into the story. It inspired me to start work on my first game, which is currently getting pretty close to done.

That's all to say, I think I'm in my copying stage. I'm trying to bring my own personality to my project, but the similarities aren't hard to see. But at the same time, I feel like you can see a solid direction that my style is going in.

Edgerton visited my fourth grade classroom. He was a North Carolinian and related to my teacher somehow, so he came in and spent a morning with us.
He showed us some of the high speed shots, but spent most of the time doing hands-on physics. As an adult, I now realize how exhausting fourth graders can be, but I remember him being patient and taking a lot of time to explain what was happening.
It's hard to describe him as an influence, since my exposure to him was so brief, but he definitely planted a seed. It was probably a decade later before I realized how cool it was to meet him.
Destin, I remember him as a kind older gentleman and I think you would have been pleased to meet him.

Imitation is how we learn. Before we can create we have to build the skills that we need to create. The best way to build those skills is by trying to copy the works of those that have the skills we want. This works, because after making a copy, we can directly compare with the original, and see how are skills need improving. Once we are confident in our skills, we can add our own creativity and come up with, and execute, original material.

I'm currently in that no man's land of not quite being sure where I'm at in terms of influence.

Back in high school, I had an amazing science teacher, Dr. Immel. This man knew more about just everything than anyone else I've known and he had studied everywhere you could imagine; Harvard, Stanford, University of Santa Cruz, and a bunch of other places I can't remember. Anyways, he taught me how to think critically, and taught me how to know myself. For the longest time I just tried to imitate him, because I was just in awe of him. And for the longest time (and partially because of him) I've wanted to go into electrical engineering, I just thought that was it. However, since then (and because of Youtube, college, etc.) I've met/seen many other people that inspire me and I want to imitate them. And I'm slowly realizing that I really want to be in manufacturing/fabrication.

In short I just wanted to say, that's my experience so far. I'm only 22 and I have much to learn, but everytime I decide there's ONE thing I want to do, I realize that that's actually not true and I'd really rather branch out into all different sects of life.

SmarterEveryDay Destin, you said you were a “copycat” as though that were a negative. Being a good copycat is really hard and forces you to understand and learn techniques.

It also forces you to understand how they were applied to achieve an effect that resonated with you. That then teaches you those techniques and quite often forces you to look at other techniques that they replaced and why they were “better” than the “standard” at the time.

All of that builds a skill set in you which adds to your abilities and a mindset that makes you challenge current standards. If you are motivated, smart and persistent those two things combined lead to you developing new things yourself.

You said you were a “copycat” who “morphed” as though it were a sidestep - i would disagree; You were a student who learned from many teachers and eventually combined that to make a forward step and create something not done before: An educational YouTube channel using high speed photography to illustrate science n a way that is beautiful, fun and entertaining.

Someone above said “you” were their inspiration and i suspect in 10 to 20 yrs time there will be hundreds of scientists, engineers and photographers out there who started their journey because of a video you put up that captured their attention and inspired them to copy you and then they never stopped.

We all stand on the shoulders of giants,. Imitation of something groundbreaking, when perfected, is the ultimate education. Edgerton gave you wings and now you fly ..... lets see how many hearts and minds you set soaring with these videos, keep it up !

So cool...so different.  Who knew you were an art lover?  This may be a weird video to you but I'm excited that you posted it.  In a strange place in life and considering much the same thing.  Where is the source of my expression coming from?  I have been a woodworker for decades and Sam Maloof was a major influence on my thinking.  But I think any Chicago school architect, Frank Lloyd Wright, Meis Van Der Roh, and the entirety of the Art Nouve period in both architecture and craft have heavily influenced my inspiration as well.  Eventually though you realize your copying and pulling and "stealing" other's creativity.  I went through a period of not wanting to design or craft anything because it seemed artificial.  It isn't until you begin to know your self and allow yourself to believe that you have a voice no matter your assessments (or anyone else's for that matter) of it that something new and unique happens.  That is what I am currently trying to do; isolate myself from negativity and believe that what is inside is my own way of communicating.  Then all the learning from those I admire will find a fresh melding into a singular voice...or something like that anyway.  It's all so new and different.  Thanks for stimulating me Destin. I've worked as a draftsman for about forty years. Forty five if you count the high school years. You could say I know how to draw a straight line...with a straight edge, of course. I've only recently started to plumb the depths of my truly artistic side, and my major influence has been M.C Escher. He has been one of my favourite artists for many years. I've been told that most of my work bears the stamp or style of a draftsman...precise and detailed. As far as developing my own style, the subjects that I find most compelling have a lot of reflections, hard edges and shadows. Very strong contrast between light and dark. The chrome on vintage cars is one of my favourite "topics", especially when I'm in a "charcoal" or graphite (pencil) mood.
I've also been working with watercolours for about eighteen years now, and am finally starting to get good enough at it to think about displaying my work in public. There are a few co-op galleries in my area that allow amateur artists to hang their works in exchange for a few hours of their time, working at the gallery.

Programmer here.  I started out creatively doing things my own way.  Then I realized that other people had already done it more efficiently and robustly.  A lot of my time is spent plugging in other people's libraries, or implementing other people's algorithms in my own context.

Working on developing my own technical style: Back in 2015, I was taking a short course in introductory aeronautics, and the teacher was using using particle-level, Newtonian physics explanations with props. This made sense to me. As the course went on and we got into drag and turbulence, those explanations stopped. I was left wondering if the particle-level, Newtonian physics explanation still held on a mass scale. They didn't seem to be able to answer my questions. My previous large accomplishment was learning graphical programming and related mathematics with both tutorials and a lot of my own time (fun fact about "gimbal lock" if you're interested that involves NASA). I knew that there were graphical programming techniques for massively parallel compute programming, so I took the next step and started learning how to run a massively parallel particle physics collision simulation using graphical computing power and rendering it in real time. It was a 2D visual, and I hard-coded some numbers, and spent long hours chasing down computer crashing errors, but it finally worked! And it was mine. And I did it. And the answer to my question was "yes" even with my amateur-level particle simulation. Now I have more ambitious plans, but these will take a while.

What's really interesting is that the steps you referenced are very similar to a style of pedagogy used in Classical Education called the Trivium. It basically states that children learn language in 3 stages: Grammar (learning the basic foundations of rules in lanuage), Logic (applying the basics of language to develop analysis/arguments/discussion) and Rhetoric (applying Grammar and Logic to instruct others). Duplicating the style/work of others is a key hallmark of the Grammar stage, before being able to apply the rules you learned in that stage towards the development of your own style in the Logic stage.

I'm still very much learning my technical skills, so I am still in the copycat phase. I do want to grow out of it as soon as possible and realize some of my more complex ideas, but I need to be sure that I can replicate what others have done so that I know that I have the basics down.

At MIT as a student you can take a class called 6.163 which is Strobe Laboratory. In that class you learn how to use strobe and triggering techniques to get the bullet shot and the milk drop shot! You then transition to high speed video and constant light and learn how to get the same shots much easier and faster. If you're ever in the Boston area, email the Edgerton Center and/or Dr Bales and/or me (I'm a student right now), I'm sure someone would be willing to show you around the place :)

I think the imitation stage is a very important step. If you just start out trying to do your own thing, if you fail it's hard to tell if it was the idea or your execution that was wrong. But if you start out trying to imitate something/someone famous then you know that the idea is fine, so the only variable left is your execution. This allows you to more clearly see what your mistakes are and how to fix them. You are able to hone your skill down to a point where you can be confident in it, so now when you start branching out on your own you can focus on the ideas stage and let your skill take care of the execution.

I'm reminded by this quote from Jean-Luc Goddard.

Nothing is original. Steal from anywhere that resonates with inspiration or fuels your imagination. Devour old films, new films, music, books, paintings, photographs, poems, dreams, random conversations, architecture, bridges, street signs, trees, clouds, bodies of water, light and shadows. Select only things to steal from that speak directly to your soul. If you do this, your work (and theft) will be authentic. Authenticity is invaluable; originality is non-existent. And don’t bother concealing your thievery - celebrate it if you feel like it. In any case, always remember what Jean-Luc Godard said: “It’s not where you take things from - it’s where you take them to."

I'm kind of disappointed that you just glossed over Edgerton's process. He revolutionized high speed photography with his work. Edgerton built upon Eadweard Muybridge's groundbreaking work with timelapse photography, which I'm sure was a big source of inspiration for him.

It was really interesting to see your evolution as a creator, but it feels like you missed a big opportunity to discuss how Edgerton accomplished what he did without modern digital camera technology. As a photographer myself that grew up shooting film, his work was very inspiring to me and there's a lot his work with analog equipment can teach people using digital gear today.

I am still copying from others I admire in my art, writing and ideas.  However, I see massive leaps regularly advancing me forward and I appreciate this stage because I recognize that if I did not start here I really wouldn’t ever get where I wanna be.  I’m rehearsing over and over and gradually I can see my own ideas and style forming out of the larger similarities of my work.  But regardless of the similarities, I love every single second of it.  I write and illustrate science picture books and poems for children and parents to gain a better understanding of how the scriptures really do predict amazing scientific discoveries and line up with what the book of nature has revealed through study.  It’s an utter joy and I’m getting really good at it.  I’ve even got permission from Dr. Hugh Ross at Reasons to Believe (Reasons.org) to tell agents and publishers that he will edit the book once a contract is arranged. I consider the use of vision research products as cheating... Edgerton used a fast flash. A modern high powered electronic flash  takes about 1ms to deliver his energy, but if you reduce the intensity to 1/128, it has in reality the same intensity but it reduces the time it is on. So instead of 1ms it lights up only for 1/128ms and then you are in the µs range, fast enough to photograph bullets in flight. Use camera settings that produce a well lit photo with 1/128 of the flash intensity and then build a trigger mechanism with adjustable delay. ;)

Copying is how we all learn.  We all first grow and mature as copy cats.  We start out as children copying the speech and mannerisms of our parents.  We learn and creat new neural pathways by copying the knowledge and experience of others. As we grow and mature we start to expand out from being mere copy cats or mimicks and become creators and teachers on our own.  Eventually becoming the ones that are copied and mimicked passing on the knowledge and experience we earned to a new generation.

Thanks for the excellent video and your excellent story.  Historically, students were often taught first by copying the "Masters", whether it's copying their paintings or sculptures, or writing the same "Hello, World!" program that tens of thousands have written before.  Copying those who went before us gives us the opportunity to judge our skills and point out areas where we need improvement, whether it's to get the breeze in the trees correct in your painting or to be able to handle recursion properly.  After one perfects his or her skills (or finds which skills may never come) can one branch out to get a style of one's own.  Your journey to your strengths is uniquely yours, but the path is well-trodden, my friend.  Keep up the good work.
